question.name: 43.1.5.3 Regression Curves - Exponential
question.questiontext:
Regression Curves - the Exponential Case

We use the same technique to look for a functional relation of the form \[ y = \alpha e^{\beta x}. \] As before, using the method of least squares, we require the values of \(a\) and \(b\) which minimize the expression \[ f(a,b) = \sum_{r=1}^n \left( y_r - a e ^{bx_r} \right)^2 . \] Again omitting the subscripts and using partial differentiation gives \[ \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial a} = -2 \sum e^{bx} \left( y - a e ^{bx} \right)\] \[ \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial b} = -2 \sum axe^{bx} \left( y - a e ^{bx} \right).\] At a minimum we require \[ \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial a} = \dfrac{\partial f}{\partial b} = 0, \] which results in the two linear equations \[ \sum y e^{bx} - a\sum e^{2bx} = 0\] \[ \sum xy e^{bx} - a\sum xe^{2bx} = 0\] which can be solved by iterative methods to give the values of \(a\) and \(b\). Note that it is possible to combine (for example) linear and exponential regression to obtain a regression equation of the form \[ y = \left( \alpha + \beta x \right) e^{\gamma x} .\] The method of least squares may then be used to find estimates \(a\), \(b\), \(c\) of \(\alpha\), \(\beta\), \(\gamma\).
